awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Portable, Inexpensive, and Robust Plasmonic Mercury Vapor Monitors
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop a robust, portable, low-power plasmonic mercury monitor capable of measuring ambient (nanograms per cubic meter) levels of mercury in air.  Environmental monitoring of mercury is a $600 million market, with an estimated $200 million spent on instruments. Incumbent instruments are adapted from automated laboratory methods requiring bulky equipment, frequent calibration, inert gasses, and high power. The method to be developed, based on gold nanoparticle films, can lower costs to operators and expand monitoring to areas currently underserved by existing systems. Of particular note are artisanal mining sites, which represent the single largest source of mercury emissions.  To expand mercury monitoring to these sites and other remote settings, a drastically less expensive, easier to operate, and more robust mercury sensing platform is needed. Beyond mercury, plasmonic sensors based on nanoparticle films have the potential to address the broader ($4 billion) chemical and biological sensing markets.

The intellectual merit of this project derives from the development of a new sensing platform based on the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) of a gold nanoparticle film. Harnessing the unique optical properties of noble metal nanoparticles for use in highly sensitive analytical instruments requires an improved understanding of the science and properly engineered controls.  Mercury sensing with gold nanoparticles provides an ideal first target for this platform. The specific aims of this project are to: improve the nanoparticle film fabrication; investigate new optical configurations to interrogate the films with light; and test and develop a packaging and control systems to handle and analyze air samples at ambient concentration levels. This research will result in a prototype plasmonic mercury sensor with a unique combination of portability and sensitivity. It will be a valuable tool in characterizing the environmental behavior of mercury and the risks to human health. Beyond mercury, the advances anticipated for this plasmonic detection platform will apply to a wide variety of chemical and biological analytes.

por.por_cntn:
The results of Picoyune’s Phase I NSF SBIR project, “Portable, Inexpensive and Robust Plasmonic Mercury Vapor Monitors,” improved understanding of the interactions of mercury vapor with plasmonic films and laid the groundwork for the further development of this technology, which will lead to better environmental monitoring and ultimately improved health outcomes.  Our plasmonic sensors use films of gold nanoparticles to detect mercury vapor, a persistent pollutant and potent neurotoxin. Picoyune’s plasmonic sensor has the potential to offer sensitive and selective detection of mercury without the complex equipment and procedure needed for the current generation of mercury sensing technology.


During the course of this project, we dramatically improved the performance of our sensor, going from a benchtop model, more suited for laboratory testing, to a portable prototype which we demonstrated for potential partners. We tested several potential interferents, improved the flow control of the system, extended the dynamic range of our sensor, and reduced system noise. At the conclusion of this project all of the lessons learned and system improvement were incorporated into the new prototype.


Beyond providing valuable information about the control, application, and performance of plasmonic films, the advancements made during this project will directly translate into a potential product to detect mercury vapor in the field. The changes made to the system directly increased the sensitivity of our sensor, allowing for more accurate detection of lower mercury concentrations. The testing of our sensor by potential partners provided a valuable side by side comparison with the current state of the art instruments and suggests a path forward for further development and eventual commercialization of this technology.
